ygData.subject: Re: Who to kill?

Subject: Re: Who to kill?

Hey Ian, I'm finally getting up to speed on SLEAT.  I've been 
traveling and unable to follow the group for a while.  

There is a clear answer to the "who to kill" question in the 
continuous case: Kill the individual in the population with the 
worst adjusted fitness.  Adjusted fitnesses should always be kept up 
to date, which means after every replacement they should be 
recalculated for the affected species.   Adjusted fitness means your 
fitness after fitness sharing has been taken into account.

Ian, it's true we faced this problem with rtNEAT and NERO.  And we 
tried several schemes.  Empirically, killing the adjusted loser 
works best.  But it also makes sense logically, because fitness 
sharing is supposed to *protect* the less competitive species, and 
you would be defeating that purpose if you killed off the absolute 
worst individual.  What if every time a new individual is born with 
new structure, it tends to suck?  Then you will keep killing off the 
innovative structures.  And that's what fitness sharing is supposed 
to protect, but it can't if you kill off the individual with 
absolute worst fitness.  So you kill the one with the worst adjusted 
fitness, and the dynamics fall back to regular NEAT.

Making NEAT continuous actually has a fair number of similar hairy 
issues, including how to use a dynamic compatibility threshold and 
how to appropriately choose the next parent species.  The ultimate 
goal is to approximate the dynamics of original NEAT.  Our papers on 
NERO address the step by step "rtNEAT" process (rtNEAT is the name I 
gave to what you're calling continuous NEAT) in explicit detail, so 
you may refer to them for guidance.  For example, see:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:utcstr-04-312

Note that this tech report should soon be replaced by a superior 
journal article which is currently in publication.  But the tech 
report does a good job of laying out the details in any case.

Another thing, which should not affect anyone, but is worth pointing 
out, is that rtNEAT is patent pending and the patent is held by UT-
Austin.  That means if you wanted to make money off of it, you'd 
have to talk to them to get a license.  Of course research doesn't 
require any permission, so this shouldnt matter to most people.  But 
it's something to consider if you have greater ambitions.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> 	That got your attention?
> 
> 	I'm starting to look at putting speciation into SLEAT.  And 
I'm wondering 
> exactly how to approach it.
> 
> 	Let me summarize NEAT-style speciation, then it will be 
easier to point 
> out where my situation diverges.
> 
> --
> 
> Species are each defined by an exemplar.  This is an individual 
chosen for 
> use in comparisons.  Any individual within some threshold 
similarity to the 
> exemplar is potentially member of the species.
> 
> Individuals are assigned to the first species that they match and 
remain in 
> the species.  Some implementations allow for periodic regeneration 
of species.
> 
> Because traditional NEAT is generational, exemplars are drawn from 
the 
> previous generation (is this right, I think the original paper is 
vague on 
> this and I know it because it was discussed here previously, but I 
forget 
> the details).  Each exemplar is one random (fittest?) member drawn 
from 
> each species in the previous generation.
> 
> Any new individual that fits no species becomes the exemplar (and 
> presumably first member) of a new species.
> 
> Any exemplar that matches no individuals from the new generation 
represents 
> a species going extinct.
> 
> The purpose of speciation is to assign offspring between groups of 
> individuals in a manner other than their simple proportion in the 
> population.  Offspring are assigned to species based on 
the "adjusted 
> fitness" which is the maximum fitness seen in the species, divided 
by the 
> number of members it has.  Offspring are assigned to each species 
according 
> to the proportions of their adjusted finesses (in 
chemical/physical speak, 
> it's a partition function).
> 
> --
> 
> 	OK, now where I differ is my system is continuous, I create 
one new 
> individual at a time, present it to the population, and somebody 
dies as a 
> result.
> 
> 	Now no part of the standard evolution scheme is incompatible 
with this, I 
> can pick individuals from species probabilistically, according to 
the 
> adjusted fitness of the species.  I can introduce individuals one 
at a time 
> and assign then to species.  I can spawn new species when an 
individual is 
> too different from any existing species...
> 
> 	But the one question that is not answered is: Who dies?
> 
> 	At present I kill the least-fit member of the population.  
But what is 
> suited when their are species.  I see three plans:
> 
> 1) kill the population loser
> 2) kill the species loser in the species getting the offspring
> 3) kill the species loser in a random species
> 4) (FOUR plans, I said FOUR) kill a completely random individual
> 
> 	What do people think?  Ken, I'm particularly interested in 
your take on 
> this because you must have just done something similar for NERO...?
> 
> 	Ian
> 
> In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
> 
> 
> 
>
